I assume Black feared 6 Ng5 d5, 7 Nxf7!? and the Fried Liver Attack.  Wouldn't want to be Black in a blitz game in that situation, but in a correspondence game it might be fun to test one's defensive prowess in that line.

On seeing this I assumed Black's purpose was to castle long.  My initial reaction was that it was a weak move since 13 Nd5 would force the Black queen to retreat right back to d8.  And I went with that, oblivious to the huge tactical threat of Black's move.

Yikes!  There should be laws against moves like this.  The White queen is toast.  I thought about resigning, then saw that White gets almost enough material compensation for the queen.  In addition, I was way ahead on development.  Perhaps then, 13 Nd5 was simply the beginning of a very deep queen sac in which I had looked deeply into the position and analyzed numerous positive variations.  Yeah, that's my story and I'm sticking to it.

There's no rush for 15 Nxc7 .  The text develops another piece with tempo, and the c7 fork will still be there for the taking.

And now I'm the equivalent of just a pawn down.  Further, all my pieces are developed whereas Black still has to get his Bf8 and his rook out.  My king position doesn't look so secure, but then neither does Black's.

Yes, this hangs the e4 pawn (since I can no longer play Bb6  after the queen takes on e4), but I thought I could utilize the open e-file as compensation.  Also, knights don't really do a whole lot on squares like a8.

Black takes the bait.  It's easy to feel invulnerable when you have a queen and your opponent does not, but White is only slightly behind on material, and has an awful lot of development as well.  Black couldn't afford to open another line of attack for the White pieces.
The Nd5 is of course immune to capture due to 28 Rc7  followed by either mate or the loss of the Black queen.

Anything else results in either mate or the loss of the queen, noted in the last comment.
And now the tables are turned.  I'm up the equivalent of a pawn and have a great attack.
The rest is mop-up.  Certainly not the result I envisioned after Black's 13.. Nf3 !

Ending with a nifty little piece sac in order to transpose to a won king and pawn ending.  Moral of the Story:  Don't despair after a blunder.  Instead, take a deep breath and size up the positives of your position.  Sometimes those positives can add up and make you look like Tal!
